cleaned_text: - 1 - CALIFORNIA LAW REVISION COMMISSION STAFF MEMORANDUM Study G-400 January 26, 2017 Memorandum 2017-5 California Public Records Act Clean-Up: Scope of Study Last year, the Legislature added a new study to the Commission's Calendar of Topics: a nonsubstantive clean-up of the California Public Records Act ("CPRA") and related provisions.1 This memorandum introduces the new study and discusses its timing, scope, and methodology. Attached for convenient reference is a copy of the CPRA (Gov't Code §§ 6250-6276.48).2 Also attached is a copy of the Richard McKee Transparency Act (Educ. Code §§ 72690-72701, 89913-89919, 92950-92961),3 as well as the following communication relating to the study: Exhibit p. Robert E. Griffin, San Luis Obispo (1/22/17) ....................... 1 TIMING In its resolution containing the Commission's current Calendar of Topics, the Legislature authorizes and requests that the California Law Revision Commission study, report on, and prepare recommended legislation as soon as possible, considering the commission's preexisting duties and workload demands, concerning the revision of the portions of the California Public Records Act and related provisions ....4 1. See 2016 Cal. Stat. res. ch. 150 (ACR 148 (Chau)). Any California Law Revision Commission document referred to in this memorandum can be obtained from the Commission. Recent materials can be downloaded from the Commission's website (www.clrc.ca.gov). Other materials can be obtained by contacting the Commission's staff, through the website or otherwise. The Commission welcomes written comments at any time during its study process. Any comments received will be a part of the public record and may be considered at a public meeting. However, comments that are received less than five business days prior to a Commission meeting may be presented without staff analysis. 2. Unless otherwise indicated, all further statutory references are to the Government Code. 3. The Richard McKee Transparency Act was enacted in 2011. Aside from technical amendments of Education Code Sections 72699 and 89918 (made by 2012 Cal. Stat. ch. 162, §§ 41, 43), it has not been revised since its enactment. 4. See 2016 Cal. Stat. res. ch. 150 (ACR 148 (Chau)) (emphasis added). - 2 - From the italicized language, it is clear that the Legislature wants the Commission to treat the CPRA study as a high priority matter. Thus, in the Commission's recent review of new topics and priorities, it decided to begin working on the CPRA study right away.5 The Commission should continue to give this study high priority, and move forward on the topic as promptly as its resources permit. OBJECTIVES The Legislature asked the Commission to achieve a number of objectives in crafting proposed legislation in this study. Specifically, that legislation must accomplish all of the following: (1) Reduce the length and complexity of current sections. (2) Avoid unnecessary cross-references. (3) Neither expand nor contract the scope of existing exemptions to the general rule that records are open to the public pursuant to the current provisions of the Public Records Act. (4) To the extent compatible with (3), use terms with common definitions. (5) Organize the existing provisions in such a way that similar provisions are located in close proximity to one another. (6) Eliminate duplicative provisions. (7) Clearly express legislative intent without any change in the substantive provisions ....6 Need For This Type of Clean-Up If one takes the time to carefully review the current statutory scheme, it becomes readily apparent that the CPRA is due for the type of attention requested by the Legislature. For example, Section 6254 is a classic overlong statute. It spans ten pages in the attached copy of the CPRA, with subdivisions numbered from (a) to (z) followed by (aa) to (ad), most of which are split into numerous paragraphs, subparagraphs, and even some unnumbered provisions.7 Overlong statutes are problematic for a number of different reasons,8 but Section 5. See Draft Minutes (Dec. 2016), pp. 3-4; see also Memorandum 2016-53, pp. 3-4, 43-44, 45. 2016 Cal. Stat. res. (ACR 148 (Chau)). 7. See CPRA Attachment pp. 11-20. 8. See Nonsubtantive Reorganization of Deadly Weapon Statutes, 38 Cal. L. Revision Comm'n Reports 217, 238-40 (2009). - 3 - 6254 suffers from an additional flaw: It conglomerates many substantively different exemptions and disclosure requirements (and various qualifications of, and limitations on, those requirements), while omitting some material that relates to key substantive provisions.9 Stanford Law School professor Michael Asimow (a Commission consultant on several studies of administrative law) probably had provisions like Section 6254 in mind when he recently welcomed the staff to the CPRA world and said: "Definitely, this is a great subject for the CLRC as the present statute is a patchwork mess."10 Nonsubstantive Nature of the Project In assigning this study, the Legislature made abundantly clear that the Commission's work is to be entirely nonsubstantive in nature. It specifically directed the Commission to "[n]either expand nor contract the scope of existing exemptions to the general rule that records are open to the public pursuant to the current provisions of the Public Records Act."11 The Legislature also asked the Commission to "use terms with common definitions," but only "[t]o the extent compatible" with the requirement to "[n]either expand nor contract the scope of existing exemptions ...."12 It further instructed the Commission to "[c]learly express legislative intent without any change in the substantive provisions."13 Analyses of the legislative resolution assigning the study, prepared while it was pending, underscore the nonsubstantive nature of the assignment. For example, the Assembly Floor analysis explains: Given the CLRC's experience in clarifying the law without affecting its substance, a request to reduce the complexity of the California Public Records Act seems appropriate.... The CPRA, signed into law in 1968 as a general record keeping law, allows the public to monitor government activity. Since the enactment of the CPRA, it has been amended multiple times to exempt certain records.... Due to the multiple changes to the statute, the CPRA has become difficult for the public to understand. In the past, the CLRC has provided hundreds of recommendations, ranging from the creation of entire codes to the repeal of a single section. Given the CLRC's experience and 9. See Sections 6254(f) (law enforcement records), 6254.30 (requirement relating to implementation of Section 6254(f)), 6262 (same), 6265 (same); see also Sections 6263 & 6264 (related provisions). 10. Email from M. Asimow to B. Gaal (1/19/17). 11. 2016 Cal. Stat. res. ch. 150 (ACR 148 (Chau)) (emphasis added). 12. Id. 13. Id. (emphasis added). - 4 - expertise in clarifying the law while maintaining the Legislature's intent, it appears reasonable and consistent with the CLRC work that the Legislature asks the CLRC to also review the CPRA to determine whether it should be revised in a non-substantive manner to reduce its length and complexity, avoid unnecessary cross-references, and eliminate duplicative provisions.14 A purely nonsubstantive approach is critical in this area, because there are many contentious issues relating to the CPRA. To give just a few examples, There are ongoing discussions about de-unification of the State Bar, prompted in part by concerns over whether CPRA requirements should apply to State Bar Sections.15 There have been recent bills about applying the CPRA to charter schools.16 A recent California Supreme Court decision addressed whether litigation invoices sent to a county by an outside law firm are subject to disclosure under the CPRA.17 A case pending before the California Supreme Court concerns whether a written communication sent or received by a public official or employee using a private electronic device is subject to the CPRA if the communication pertains to city business.18 A 2010 speech by Sarah Palin at CSU Stanislaus prompted debates and legislation about invoking the CPRA to obtain speaking contracts (and other contracts) from CSU auxiliaries and certain other quasi-public entities.19 To avoid creating concerns over its proposed legislation, the Commission will need to (1) stick closely to the existing language of the CPRA and (2) use the 14. Assembly Floor Analysis of ACR 148 (Chau) (Aug. 18, 2016), p. 3 (italics in original). 15. See, e.g., Laura Ernde, Board Panel Hears Pros and Cons of Dividing State Bar Roles, Cal. Bar J. (May 2016), available at http://www.calbarjournal.com/May2016/TopHeadlines/TH2.aspx; see also Section 6252(f)(2) (As used in CPRA, "state agency" includes State Bar). 16. See AB 709 (Gipson), which passed the Legislature in 2016, but was vetoed by the Governor. AB 913 (Chau) was a similar bill in the 2013-2014 legislative session, which Governor Brown also vetoed. For further discussion of this issue, see Charter Schools and the Government Claims Act, 42 Cal. L. Revision Comm'n Reports 225, 264-65 (2012). 17. See Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors v. Superior Court, 2 Cal. 5th 282 (2016). 18. See City of San Jose v. Superior Court (No. S218066). 19. See, e.g., Lance Williams, Documents Detailing Palin's CSU Speaking Fee Were Shredded (June 13, 2010), available at http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/04/13/documents-detailing-palin_n_535669.html; 2011 Cal. Stat. ch. 247 (SB 8 (Yee)); SB 218 (Yee) (2009-2010 Reg. Sess.). - 5 - other techniques it has developed over the years to ensure that a recodification effects no substantive change.20 Additional Guiding Principles for Preparing the Commission's Recommendation In addition to complying with the legislative directive to make no substantive change, the Commission may wish to follow a few other guiding principles in conducting this study. In particular, in its study on recodifying the Fish and Game Code, the Commission recently determined that a proposed change should only be considered for inclusion in the proposed law if it meets all three of the following criteria: (1) It is plainly beneficial. (2) It does not present a significant risk of unintended consequences (i.e., its effects seem straightforward and circumscribed). (3) It is not likely to be controversial.21 These three criteria "are grounded in pragmatic concerns about the difficulty of achieving enactment" of a bulky recodification bill.22 "With a proposal of this type and size, the Legislature needs to receive a noncontroversial bill, so that it can focus its analytical resources on the primary purpose of the bill: to make the [statutory material] easier to use and understand."23 When it adopted the above criteria for use in the Fish and Game study, the Commission indicated that they "should probably be used in any future technical clean-up project."24 Would the Commission like to apply the three criteria shown above in its study of the CPRA? SCOPE OF STUDY The legislative resolution instructs the Commission to "study, report on, and prepare recommended legislation ... concerning the revision of the portions of the 20. For a description of those techniques, see Nonsubtantive Reorganization of Deadly Weapon Statutes, supra note 7, at 231-37. 21. Minutes (Sept. 2016), p. 6. 22. Memorandum 2009-53, pp. 45-46; see also First Supplement to Memorandum 2016-47, p. 6. 23. Memorandum 2009-53, pp. 45-46; see also First Supplement to Memorandum 2016-47, p. 6. 24. Minutes (Sept. 2016), p. 6. - 6 - California Public Records Act and related provisions ...."25 Key issues relating to the scope of this study are: Which statutory provisions to include in the study, and How to handle Article 2 of the CPRA (Gov't Code §§ 6275-6276.48). Those issues are discussed in order below. Which Statutory Provisions to Include in the Study As originally introduced, the legislative resolution instructed the Commission to "study, report on, and prepare recommended legislation ... concerning the revision of the portions of the Government Code relating to public records ...."26 The Commission raised questions about that language and asked the staff to "investigate whether the scope of the study is limited to the four corners of the Public Records Act or would also include closely-related law located elsewhere in the codes ...."27 For example, the Commission was interested in whether the study would encompass the Education Code provisions added in 2011 governing access to records of CSU auxiliaries and certain other quasi-public entities (known as "The Richard McKee Transparency Act of 2011").28 It was also unclear whether the study was supposed to relate solely to public records inspection law, or should also encompass other aspects of public records law, such as records management.29 After the staff raised those questions with legislative staff, the resolution was amended to include the current language, which directs the Commission to "study, report on, and prepare recommended legislation ... concerning the revision of the portions of the California Public Records Act and related provisions ...." Thus, the study does not appear to be limited to provisions in the Government Code, but does appear to be limited to public records inspection law, not other aspects of public records law. The bill analyses seem to be consistent with that 25. 2016 Cal. Stat. res. ch. 150 (ACR 148 (Chau)) (emphasis added). 26. ACR 148 (Chau), as introduced on March 3, 2016. 27. Minutes (April 2016), p. 3. 28. See id.; see also Educ. Code see also Gov't Code §§ 6200-6203 (crimes relating to public records), 6204-6204.4 (public record protection and recovery), 6205-6210 (confidentiality of certain records about crime victims), 12220-12237 (state archives). - 7 - view, though they do not shed much light on it.30 Unless the Commission otherwise directs, the staff will proceed accordingly in researching which provisions to bring to the Commission's attention. Consistent with that approach, the Commission will need to specifically resolve whether to include the Richard McKee Transparency Act within the scope of this study. That Act incorporates some CPRA provisions by reference31 and also contains other provisions relating to record inspection. A copy of the Act is attached for the Commission to consider.32 The Commission has received a message from Robert E. Griffin encouraging it to include the Richard McKee Transparency Act within the scope of the Commission's study.33 He says that the Act "has represented an awkward and largely unnecessarily detailed overlay of the CPRA" and auxiliary organizations "struggle to reconcile its requirements with those under the CPRA used by the CSU and its campuses."34 He urges the Commission to "give the McKee Act a close read and ... consider its relationship to the CPRA."35 He believes that it "represents precisely" the type of issues associated with the objectives of the Commission's study.36 The staff is still gaining familiarity with the Richard McKee Transparency Act, but tentatively recommends including it within the Commission's study. Does the Commission want to take that approach? The staff is also beginning to review the codes to determine which other provisions warrant attention in this study. We welcome advice on that matter. How to Handle Article 2 of the CPRA (Gov't Code §§ 6275-6276.48) Article 1 §§ 6250-6270.5) is entitled "General Provisions." This article consists of substantive provisions governing access to public records. 30. See Senate Committee on Judiciary Analysis of ACR 148 (Chau) (June 13, 2016); Senate Floor Analysis of ACR 148 (Chau) (Aug. 15, 2016); Assembly Floor Analysis of ACR 148 (Chau) (Aug. 18, 2016). 31. See Educ. Code §§ 72695, 89915.5, 92955. 32. The Richard McKee Transparency Act was enacted in 2011. Aside from technical amendments of Education Code Sections 72699 and 89918 (made by 2012 Cal. Stat. ch. 162, §§ 41, 43), it has not been revised since its enactment. 33. See Exhibit. 34. Id. 35. Id. 36. Id. - 8 - Article 2 of the CPRA (Gov't Code §§ 6275-6276.48) is entitled "Other Exemptions from Disclosure." This article is quite unusual. It begins with the following statement of legislative intent: It is the intent of the Legislature to assist members of the public and state and local agencies in identifying exemptions to the California Public Records Act. It is the intent of the Legislature that, after January 1, 1999, each addition or amendment to a statute that exempts any information contained in a public record from disclosure pursuant to subdivision (k) of Section 625437 shall be listed and described in this article pursuant to a bill authorized by a standing committee of the Legislature to be introduced during the first year of each session of the Legislature. The statutes and constitutional provisions listed in this article may operate to exempt certain records, or portions thereof, from disclosure. The statutes and constitutional provisions listed and described may not be inclusive of all exemptions. The listing of a statute or constitutional provision in this article does not itself create an exemption. Requesters of public records and public agencies are cautioned to review the applicable statute or constitutional provision to determine the extent to which it, in light of the circumstances surrounding the request, exempts public records from disclosure.38 The article is thus intended to be a tool to assist persons in locating CPRA exemptions. It lists exemptions created in other code provisions (mostly located outside the CPRA), rather than creating any exemptions itself. The next provision in Article 2 makes clear that the article's list of exemptions is not necessarily complete. It states that "[r]ecords or information not required to be disclosed pursuant to subdivision (k) of Section 6254 may include, but shall not be limited to, records or information identified in statutes listed in this article."39 The remainder of the article consists of the list of CPRA exemptions. It starts with a code section that refers to an exemption located in the California Constitution.40 The article then lists numerous statutory exemptions. That list 37. (k) Records, the disclosure of which is exempted or prohibited pursuant to federal or state law, including, but not limited to, provisions of the Evidence Code relating to privilege. 38. Section 6276.02 is typical. It provides as follows: 6276.02. The staff does not know how well the list in Article 2 (hereafter, the "CPRA Index") is serving its intended purpose. Input on that point would be extremely helpful. In the course of studying the CPRA, the Commission will need to decide what to do with Article 2. Should it recommend that the Legislature retain and continue to update the article each legislative session? Should the provisions currently listed in Article 2 but located outside the CPRA be moved into the CPRA, thus separating them from the substantive material that currently surrounds them? Should Article 2 be repealed and replaced with another statutory tool that serves a similar function? Should Article 2 simply be repealed, without replacing it? The Commission does not have to resolve these questions yet, but it will need to do so soon. We much encourage comments on this matter. METHODOLOGY The Legislature did not prescribe any special methodology for the Commission to use in its study of the CPRA. Presumably, the Legislature intended for the Commission to use its normal study process, which is careful, deliberative, and time-tested. Several aspects of that process are discussed below. - 11 - General Description of Study Process The Commission's study process is described in detail in its Annual Report.41 Sometimes the Commission hires a consultant (usually a law professor) to prepare a background study before the Commission begins considering a topic. Because this particular study will be purely technical in nature and the Legislature has expressed some urgency, the background research will be done by the staff, not by a consultant. Interested persons are invited to bring relevant materials to the staff's attention. In conducting a study, the Commission holds a series of public meetings, at which it makes decisions about how to proceed (what issues to investigate, what reforms to propose, how those reforms should be drafted, and the like). Before each meeting, the staff prepares and distributes a memorandum that serves as the basis for discussion at the meeting. These memoranda are posted on the Commission's website at <www.clrc.ca.gov>. By following the instructions at <http://www.clrc.ca.gov/G400.html>, interested persons can subscribe to receive the memoranda for this study electronically as they are generated; persons can also request to be on the Commission's traditional mailing list. After becoming familiar with a topic and making preliminary decisions, preparation of a tentative recommendation begins. A tentative recommendation has three main components: (1) proposed legislation, (2) a Commission Comment to each section of the proposed legislation, and (3) a narrative explanation of the reform (the "preliminary part"). The tentative recommendation is widely circulated to interested persons for comment. The comment period is usually about three months. During the comment period, it is just as important for an interested person to express support for the proposal as it is to express disapproval. The Commission then considers the comments at one or more public meetings and determines what, if any, recommendation it will make to the Legislature. The Commission will often substantially revise a proposal in response to comment it receives. After the Commission approves a final recommendation, the proposal must go through the same legislative process as any other legislative proposal. The 41. The Commission's 2014-2015 Annual Report is available in preprint format at http://www.clrc.ca.gov/pub/Printed-Reports/Pub239-AR14.pdf. See in particular pages 14-22. For further information on the Commission's study process, see http://www.clrc.ca.gov/Menu5_about/process.html; see also Barbara Gaal, Evidence Legislation in California, 36 Sw. Univ. L. Rev. 561, 563-69 (2008). - 12 - staff provides the Commission's final recommendation (including the proposed legislation, Commission Comments, and preliminary part) to the policy committees and the Governor. It is properly regarded as legislative history, indicative of legislative intent.42 The process of preparing a final recommendation, even on a narrow, simple, and straightforward topic, takes a minimum of a year, often several years. Then it generally takes at least another year before the proposal is enacted. Legislation generally becomes operative on January 1st of the year following its enactment.43 Participation By Interested Persons The Commission's longstanding practice is to welcome participation by any interested individual or organization in its study process. All Commission meetings are open to the public and members of the public are given opportunities to participate in the discussion. Written comments can be submitted at any time, by mail, email, or other method of delivery. Comments relating to this study should be directed to Barbara Gaal or Steve Cohen. Their contact information is as follows: Barbara Gaal Steve Cohen California Law Revision Comm'n California Law Revision Comm'n 4000 Middlefield Road, Room D-2 c/o UC Davis School of Law Palo Alto, CA 94303 Davis, CA 95616 Email: <bgaal@clrc.ca.gov> Email: <scohen@clrc.ca.gov> Comments received shortly before a Commission meeting may not be analyzed and considered as thoroughly as comments received well in advance. Comments are especially encouraged and solicited during the comment period on a tentative recommendation. Persons or organizations with limited resources may want to focus on providing comments at this stage of the Commission's study. Efforts to Build the Mailing List for This Study The staff is still in the process of building its electronic and traditional mailing lists for this study. The Commission has not previously worked on the CPRA, so it does not already have a suitable mailing list in place. 42. See 2014-2015 Annual Report, supra note 41, at 16-22 & cases cited therein. 43. See Cal. Const. art. IV, § 8(c)(1); Gov't Code § 9600(a). - 13 - Suggestions about persons and organizations to include on the mailing list would be helpful. In a future memorandum, we will update the Commission on our progress and efforts to reach out to stakeholders. Code Organization and Statutory Numbering Scheme In conducting this study, the Commission will need to consider the best means of reorganizing the CPRA and related material. That almost certainly will entail renumbering and relocating some provisions, because Article 1 of the CPRA is currently a jumble of substantive material. It might also be advisable to add more articles to the chapter that contains the CPRA, or make other revisions to the hierarchy within the Government Code. It is too early for the Commission to make any decisions about precisely how to reorganize the CPRA and related material. Stakeholders may be interested to know, however, that when the Commission proposes to relocate statutory material, it routinely also proposes a provision designed to ease the transition to the new numbering scheme. For example, the following Penal Code provision was enacted into law in conjunction with the Commission's recent recodification of the deadly weapons statutes: 16010. (a) A provision of this part or of Title 2 (commencing with Section 12001) of Part 4, or any other provision of the Deadly Weapons Recodification Act of 2010, insofar as it is substantially the same as a previously existing provision relating to the same subject matter, shall be considered as a restatement and continuation thereof and not as a new enactment. (b) A reference in a statute to a previously existing provision that is restated and continued in this part or in Title 2 (commencing with Section 12001) of Part 4, or in any other provision of the Deadly Weapons Recodification Act of 2010, shall, unless a contrary intent appears, be deemed a reference to the restatement and continuation. (c) A reference in a statute to a provision of this part or of Title 2 (commencing with Section 12001) of Part 4, or any other provision of the Deadly Weapons Recodification Act of 2010, which is substantially the same as a previously existing provision, shall, unless a contrary intent appears, be deemed to include a reference to the previously existing provision. The Commission could include a similar provision in its recodification of the CPRA and related provisions. Is the staff correct in assuming that the Commission would like to include such a provision? - 14 - Reference Materials The staff is still coming up to speed on this new topic. We would appreciate suggestions regarding any treatises, reference works, or other background materials that might be useful in conducting the study. PENDING BILLS Some pending bills would make revisions relating to the CPRA.44 The Commission's study will not interfere with those bills; it should not have any impact on their fate or the fate of any future bills. The role of the Commission is simply to make recommendations to the Legislature on topics assigned to it for study. The Commission does not take positions on legislation proposed by others. If CPRA-related legislation is enacted while the Commission is conducting this study, the Commission will take the new legislation into account in developing its proposal. If CPRA-related legislation is pending at the same time that the Commission's proposal is pending, any bill conflict could be resolved through bill coordination amendments. NEXT STEPS Unless the Commission otherwise instructs, the staff's next step will be to work on a proposed outline for reorganization of the CPRA and related provisions. This outline will be very tentative and preliminary in nature, because it will still be necessary for the Commission to address and resolve some fundamental issues (e.g., identifying all of the statutory provisions to include and determining how to handle Article 2 of the CPRA). Respectfully submitted, Steve Cohen Staff Counsel Barbara Gaal Chief Deputy Counsel 44. Similarly, AB 73 (Chiu & Cabellero) (as introduced on Dec. 16, 2016) would specify that certain monthly reports are public records under the CPRA and shall be open to public inspection. - i- CALIFORNIA PUBLIC RECORDS ACT (GOV'T CODE §§ 6250-6276.48) TABLE OF CONTENTS TITLE 1. GENERAL 1 ... DIVISION 7. MISCELLANEOUS 2 ... CHAPTER 3.5. INSPECTION OF PUBLIC RECORDS 3 Article 1. General Provisions 4 § 6250. Legislative finding and declaration 5 6250. In enacting this chapter, the Legislature, mindful of the right of 6 individuals to privacy, finds and declares that access to information concerning the 7 conduct of the people's business is a fundamental and necessary right of every 8 person in this state. 9 § 6251. Name of act 10 6251. This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the California Public 11 Records Act. 12 § 6252. Definitions 13 6252. As used in this chapter: 14 (a) "Local agency" includes a county; city, whether general law or chartered; 15 city and county; school district; municipal corporation; district; political 16 subdivision; or any board, commission or agency thereof; other local public 17 agency; or entities that are legislative bodies of a local agency pursuant to 18 subdivisions (c) and (d) of Section 54952. 19 (b) "Member of the public" means any person, except a member, agent, officer, 20 or employee of a federal, state, or local agency acting within the scope of his or 21 her membership, agency, office, or employment. 22 (c) "Person" includes any natural person, corporation, partnership, limited 23 liability company, firm, or association. 24 (d) "Public agency" means any state or local agency. 25 (e) "Public records" includes any writing containing information relating to the 26 conduct of the public's business prepared, owned, used, or retained by any state or 27 local agency regardless of physical form or characteristics. "Public records" in the 28 custody of, or maintained by, the Governor's office means any writing prepared on 29 or after January 6, 1975. 30 - 2- (f)(1) "State agency" means every state office, officer, department, division, 1 bureau, board, and commission or other state body or agency, except those 2 agencies provided for in Article IV (except Section 20 thereof) or Article VI of the 3 California Constitution. 4 (2) Notwithstanding paragraph (1) or any other law, "state agency" shall also 5 mean the State Bar of California, as described in Section 6001 of the Business and 6 Professions Code. 7 (g) "Writing" means any handwriting, typewriting, printing, photostating, 8 photographing, photocopying, transmitting by electronic mail or facsimile, and 9 every other means of recording upon any tangible thing any form of 10 communication or representation, including letters, words, pictures, sounds, or 11 symbols, or combinations thereof, and any record thereby created, regardless of 12 the manner in which the record has been stored. 13 § 6252.5. Access by elected member or officer of agency 14 6252.5. Notwithstanding the definition of "member of the public" in Section 15 6252, an elected member or officer of any state or local agency is entitled to 16 access to public records of that agency on the same basis as any other person. 17 Nothing in this section shall limit the ability of elected members or officers to 18 access public records permitted by law in the administration of their duties. 19 This section does not constitute a change in, but is declaratory of, existing law. 20 § 6252.6. Procedures governing access to public records subject to disclosure 34 6253. (a) Public records are open to inspection at all times during the office 35 hours of the state or local agency and every person has a right to inspect any 36 public record, except as hereafter provided. Any reasonably segregable portion of 37 a record shall be available for inspection by any person requesting the record after 38 deletion of the portions that are exempted by law. 39 - 3- (b) Except with respect to public records exempt from disclosure by express 1 provisions of law, each state or local agency, upon a request for a copy of records 2 that reasonably describes an identifiable record or records, shall make the records 3 promptly available to any person upon payment of fees covering direct costs of 4 duplication, or a statutory fee if applicable. Upon request, an exact copy shall be 5 provided unless impracticable to do so. 6 (c) Each agency, upon a request for a copy of records, shall, within 10 days from 7 receipt of the request, determine whether the request, in whole or in part, seeks 8 copies of disclosable public records in the possession of the agency and shall 9 promptly notify the person making the request of the determination and the 10 reasons therefor. In unusual circumstances, the time limit prescribed in this section 11 may be extended by written notice by the head of the agency or his or her designee 12 to the person making the request, setting forth the reasons for the extension and 13 the date on which a determination is expected to be dispatched. No notice shall 14 specify a date that would result in an extension for more than 14 days. When the 15 agency dispatches the determination, and if the agency determines that the request 16 seeks disclosable public records, the agency shall state the estimated date and time 17 when the records will be made available. As used in this section, "unusual 18 circumstances" means the following, but only to the extent reasonably necessary 19 to the proper processing of the particular request: 20 (1) The need to search for and collect the requested records from field facilities 21 or other establishments that are separate from the office processing the request. 22 (2) The need to search for, collect, and appropriately examine a voluminous 23 amount of separate and distinct records that are demanded in a single request. 24 (3) The need for consultation, which shall be conducted with all practicable 25 speed, with another agency having substantial interest in the determination of the 26 request or among two or more components of the agency having substantial 27 subject matter interest therein. 28 (4) The need to compile data, to write programming language or a computer 29 program, or to construct a computer report to extract data. 30 (d) Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to permit an agency to delay or 31 obstruct the inspection or copying of public records. The notification of denial of 32 any request for records required by Section 6255 shall set forth the names and 33 titles or positions of each person responsible for the denial. 34 (e) Except as otherwise prohibited by law, a state or local agency may adopt 35 requirements for itself that allow for faster, more efficient, or greater access to 36 records than prescribed by the minimum standards set forth in this chapter. 37 (f) In addition to maintaining public records for public inspection during the 38 office hours of the public agency, a public agency may comply with subdivision 39 (a) by posting any public record on its Internet Web site and, in response to a 40 request for a public record posted on the Internet Web site, directing a member of 41 the public to the location on the Internet Web site where the public record is 42 posted. However, if after the public agency directs a member of the public to the 43 - 4- Internet Web site, the member of the public requesting the public record requests a 1 copy of the public record due to an inability to access or reproduce the public 2 record from the Internet Web site, the public agency shall promptly provide a copy 3 of the public record pursuant to subdivision (b). 4 § 6253.1. However, if, for identification purposes, a state or local law enforcement 3 agency requires identification in order for a victim of an incident, or an authorized 4 representative thereof, to obtain that information, the agency shall, at a minimum, 5 accept a current driver's license or identification card issued by any state in the 6 United States, a current passport issued by the United States or a foreign 7 government with which the United States has a diplomatic relationship, or a 8 current Matricula Consular card. 9 § 6254.33. Unique vendor, contractor, or affiliate identifying information 10 6254.33. Nothing in this chapter shall require the disclosure of an identification 11 number, alphanumeric character, or other unique identifying code that a public 12 agency uses to identify a vendor or contractor, or an affiliate of a vendor or 13 contractor, unless the identification number, alphanumeric character, or other 14 unique identifying code is used in a public bidding or an audit involving the public 15 agency. 16 § 6255. Required justification and procedure for withholding of record 17 6255. (a) The agency shall justify withholding any record by demonstrating that 18 the record in question is exempt under express provisions of this chapter or that on 19 the facts of the particular case the public interest served by not disclosing the 20 record clearly outweighs the public interest served by disclosure of the record. 21 (b) A response to a written request for inspection or copies of public records that 22 includes a determination that the request is denied, in whole or in part, shall be in 23 writing. 24 § 6257.5. Prohibition on limitation of access based on purpose of request 25 6257.5. This chapter does not allow limitations on access to a public record 26 based upon the purpose for which the record is being requested, if the record is 27 otherwise subject to disclosure. 28 § 6258. Judicial proceeding for enforcement of right to inspect or receive record 29 6258. Any person may institute proceedings for injunctive or declarative relief 30 or writ of mandate in any court of competent jurisdiction to enforce his or her right 31 to inspect or to receive a copy of any public record or class of public records under 32 this chapter. The times for responsive pleadings and for hearings in these 33 proceedings shall be set by the judge of the court with the object of securing a 34 decision as to these matters at the earliest possible time. 35 § 6259. Procedure for petition alleging improper withholding of public record 36 6259. (a) Whenever it is made to appear by verified petition to the superior court 37 of the county where the records or some part thereof are situated that certain 38 - 39- public records are being improperly withheld from a member of the public, the 1 court shall order the officer or person charged with withholding the records to 2 disclose the public record or show cause why he or she should not do so. The court 3 shall decide the case after examining the record in camera, if permitted by 4 subdivision (b) of Section 915 of the Evidence Code, papers filed by the parties 5 and any oral argument and additional evidence as the court may allow. 6 (b) If the court finds that the public official's decision to refuse disclosure is not 7 justified under Section 6254 or 6255, he or she shall order the public official to 8 make the record public. If the judge determines that the public official was 9 justified in refusing to make the record public, he or she shall return the item to the 10 public official without disclosing its content with an order supporting the decision 11 refusing disclosure. 12 (c) In an action filed on or after January 1, 1991, an order of the court, either 13 directing disclosure by a public official or supporting the decision of the public 14 official refusing disclosure, is not a final judgment or order within the meaning of 15 Section 904.1 of the Code of Civil Procedure from which an appeal may be taken, 16 but shall be immediately reviewable by petition to the appellate court for the 17 issuance of an extraordinary writ. Upon entry of any order pursuant to this section, 18 a party shall, in order to obtain review of the order, file a petition within 20 days 19 after service upon him or her of a written notice of entry of the order, or within 20 such further time not exceeding an additional 20 days as the trial court may for 21 good cause allow. If the notice is served by mail, the period within which to file 22 the petition shall be increased by five days. A stay of an order or judgment shall 23 not be granted unless the petitioning party demonstrates it will otherwise sustain 24 irreparable damage and probable success on the merits. Any person who fails to 25 obey the order of the court shall be cited to show cause why he or she is not in 26 contempt of court. 27 (d) The court shall award court costs and reasonable attorney fees to the plaintiff 28 should the plaintiff prevail in litigation filed pursuant to this section. The costs and 29 fees shall be paid by the public agency of which the public official is a member or 30 employee and shall not become a personal liability of the public official. If the 31 court finds that the plaintiff's case is clearly frivolous, it shall award court costs 32 and reasonable attorney fees to the public agency. 33 § 6260. Effect of chapter 34 6260. The provisions of this chapter shall not be deemed in any manner to affect 35 the status of judicial records as it existed immediately prior to the effective date of 36 this section, nor to affect the rights of litigants, including parties to administrative 37 proceedings, under the laws of discovery of this state, nor to limit or impair any 38 rights of discovery in a criminal case. 39 - 40- § 6261. Patron use records of publicly-supported library 26 6267. All patron use records of any library which is in whole or in part 27 supported by public funds shall remain confidential and shall not be disclosed by a 28 public agency, or private actor that maintains or stores patron use records on 29 behalf of a public agency, to any person, local agency, or state agency except as 30 follows: 31 (a) By a person acting within the scope of his or her duties within the 32 administration of the library. 33 (b) By a person authorized, in writing, by the individual to whom the records 34 pertain, to inspect the records. 35 (c) By order of the appropriate superior court. 36 As used in this section, the term "patron use records" includes the following: 37 - 41- (1) Any written or electronic record, that is used to identify the patron, 1 including, but not limited to, a patron's name, address, telephone number, or e-2 mail address, that a library patron provides in order to become eligible to borrow 3 or use books and other materials. 4 (2) Any written record or electronic transaction that identifies a patron's 5 borrowing information or use of library information resources, including, but not 6 limited to, database search records, borrowing records, class records, and any 7 other personally identifiable uses of library resources information requests, or 8 inquiries. 9 This section shall not apply to statistical reports of patron use nor to records of 10 fines collected by the library. 11 § 6268. Archiving and disclosure of Governor's public records 12 6268. Public records, as defined in Section 6252, in the custody or control of the 13 Governor when he or she leaves office, either voluntarily or involuntarily, shall, as 14 soon as is practical, be transferred to the State Archives. Notwithstanding any 15 other provision of law, the Governor, by written instrument, the terms of which 16 shall be made public, may restrict public access to any of the transferred public 17 records, or any other writings he or she may transfer, which have not already been 18 made accessible to the public. With respect to public records, public access, as 19 otherwise provided for by this chapter, shall not be restricted for a period greater 20 than 50 years or the death of the Governor, whichever is later, nor shall there be 21 any restriction whatsoever with respect to enrolled bill files, press releases, speech 22 files, or writings relating to applications for clemency or extradition in cases 23 which have been closed for a period of at least 25 years. Subject to any restrictions 24 permitted by this section, the Secretary of State, as custodian of the State 25 Archives, shall make all such public records and other writings available to the 26 public as otherwise provided for in this chapter. 27 Except as to enrolled bill files, press releases, speech files, or writings relating to 28 applications for clemency or extradition, this section shall not apply to public 29 records or other writings in the direct custody or control of any Governor who held 30 office between 1974 and 1988 at the time of leaving office, except to the extent 31 that that Governor may voluntarily transfer those records or other writings to the 32 State Archives. 33 Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the public records and other 34 writings of any Governor who held office between 1974 and 1988 may be 35 transferred to any educational or research institution in California provided that 36 with respect to public records, public access, as otherwise provided for by this 37 chapter, shall not be restricted for a period greater than 50 years or the death of the 38 Governor, whichever is later. No records or writings may be transferred pursuant 39 to this paragraph unless the institution receiving them agrees to maintain, and does 40 maintain, the materials according to commonly accepted archival standards. No 41 public records transferred shall be destroyed by that institution without first 42 - 42- receiving the written approval of the Secretary of State, as custodian of the State 1 Archives, who may require that the records be placed in the State Archives rather 2 than being destroyed. An institution receiving those records or writings shall allow 3 the Secretary of State, as custodian of the State Archives, to copy, at state expense, 4 and to make available to the public, any and all public records, and inventories, 5 indices, or finding aids relating to those records, which the institution makes 6 available to the public generally. Copies of those records in the custody of the 7 State Archives shall be given the same legal effect as is given to the originals. 8 § 6268.5. Catalog of enterprise systems 29 6270.5. (a) In implementing this chapter, each local agency, except a local 30 educational agency, shall create a catalog of enterprise systems. pursuant to this chapter. 5 (c) For purposes of this section: 6 (1) "Enterprise system" means a software application or computer system that 7 collects, stores, exchanges, and analyzes information record" means a system that serves as an original source of data 13 within an agency. 14 (3) An enterprise system shall not include any of the following: 15 (A) Information technology security systems, including firewalls and other 16 cybersecurity systems. 17 (B) Physical access control systems, employee identification management 18 systems, video monitoring, and other physical control systems. 19 (C) Infrastructure and mechanical control systems, including those that control 20 or manage street lights, electrical, natural gas, or water or sewer functions. 21 (D) Systems related to 911 dispatch and operation or emergency services. 22 (E) Systems that would be restricted from disclosure pursuant to Section 23 6254.19. 24 (F) The specific records that the information technology system collects, stores, 25 exchanges, or analyzes. 26 (d) Nothing in this section shall be construed to permit public access to records 27 held by an agency to which access is otherwise restricted by statute or to alter the 28 process for requesting public records, as set forth in this chapter. 29 (e) If, on the facts of the particular case, the public interest served by not 30 disclosing the information described in paragraph (1) or (2) of subdivision (a) 31 clearly outweighs the public interest served by disclosure of the record, the local 32 agency may instead provide a system name, brief title, or identifier of the system. 33 (f) The local agency shall complete and post the catalog required by this section 34 by July 1, 2016, and thereafter shall update the catalog annually. 35 It is the intent of the Legislature to assist members of the public and state 3 and local agencies in identifying exemptions to the California Public Records Act. 4 It is the intent of the Legislature that, after January 1, 1999, each addition or 5 amendment to a statute that exempts any information contained in a public record 6 from disclosure pursuant to subdivision (k) of Section 6254 shall be listed and 7 described in this article pursuant to a bill authorized by a standing committee of 8 the Legislature to be introduced during the first year of each session of the 9 Legislature. The 11 statutes and constitutional provisions listed and described may not be inclusive of 12 all exemptions. Filed with Secretary of State September 06, 2011. ]LEGISLATIVE)COUNSEL.S)DIGESTSB 8, Yee. Public records: auxiliary organizations and UC campus foundations.The California Public Records Act requires state and local agencies to make their records available for publicinspection and to make copies available upon request and payment of a fee unless those records are exemptfrom disclosure.Existing law establishes the segments of the public postsecondary education system in the state, including theUniversity of California administered by the Regents of the University of California, the California StateUniversity administered by the Trustees of the California State University, and the California CommunityColleges administered by the Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges.This bill would require records maintained by an auxiliary organization of the governing board of a communitycollege district, the Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges, and California State University,as defined, or a University of California (UC) campus foundation, as defined, to be available to the public toinspect or copy at all times during the office hours of the organization or foundation, as specified. The billwould require an auxiliary organization and a UC campus foundation to follow specified requirements whenfulfilling or denying a request for a record. The bill would prohibit specified records maintained by an auxiliaryorganization or UC campus foundation from being subject to disclosure. The bill would prohibit an auxiliaryorganization from disclosing trade secrets, as defined, and would require this information to be redacted fromthe organization's records before disclosure. The bill would provide specified judicial relief to persons seekingdisclosure of records from an auxiliary organization or a UC campus foundation pursuant to this bill. The billwould require a disclosure of a record, which is exempt from disclosure, by an auxiliary organization or a UCcampus foundation to constitute a waiver of the exemptions provided by this bill with regard to that record, HomeBill records: auxiliary organizations and UC campus foundations. Page 2 of 15http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billNavClient.xhtml?bill_id=201120120SB8except as specified. The bill would provide that a contract entered into after the effective date of this bill,which would prevent the disclosure of information required to be disclosed pursuant to this bill, is void andunenforceable. The bill would provide that its provisions do not apply to any records subject to a request madepursuant to the California Public Records Act.Vote: majority Appropriation: no Fiscal Committee: no Local Program: no THE)PEOPLE)OF)THE)STATE)OF)CALIFORNIA)DO)ENACT)AS)FOLLOWS:SECTION 1. Article 7 (commencing with Section 72690) is added to Chapter 6 of Part 45 of Division 7 of Title3 of the Education Code, to read:Article 7. The Richard McKee Transparency Act of 201172690. The Legislature finds and declares all of the following:(a) Access to information concerning the conduct of the people's business is a necessary and fundamentalright of every person in this state.(b) The auxiliary organizations of a governing board of a community college district and of the Board ofGovernors of the California Community Colleges promote and assist the colleges by engaging in activities thatare essential and integral to the mission and purpose of the California Community Colleges.(c) The auxiliary organizations of a governing board of a community college district and of the Board ofGovernors of the California Community Colleges are legally separate from the California Community Colleges.(d) Access to records used, owned, or maintained by these auxiliary organizations must be balanced by theneed to protect the individual privacy rights of donors and volunteers, and to protect an auxiliaryorganization's fiduciary interests.72691. For purposes of this article, the following terms have the following meanings:(a) "Auxiliary organization" means those entities defined in Sections 72670 "Identifiable writing" means any handwriting, typewriting, printing, photostating, photographing,photocopying, transmitting by electronic mail or facsimile, and every other means of recording upon anytangible thing, any form of communication or representation, including, but not limited to, letters, words,pictures, sounds, or symbols, or combinations thereof, and any record thereby created, regardless of themanner in which the record has been stored.72692. (a) Records maintained by an auxiliary organization shall be available to the public to inspect or copy atall times during the office hours of the auxiliary organization, except as hereafter provided. The recordssubject to inspection or copying by the public pursuant to this section shall include any identifiable writingcontaining information relating to the conduct of the auxiliary organization that is prepared, owned, used, orretained by an auxiliary organization. Any reasonably segregable portion of a record shall be promptlyavailable for inspection and copying after redacting those portions exempt from disclosure by law.(b) Upon a request for a copy of a record that reasonably describes an identifiable record, an auxiliaryorganization shall make the record promptly available within a reasonable time to any person upon payment offees covering only the direct cost of duplication, except with respect to records maintained by an auxiliaryorganization exempt from disclosure by law. Nothing in this article shall be construed to permit an auxiliaryorganization to delay or obstruct the inspection or copying of public records.(c) If a member of the public requests to inspect a public record or obtain a copy of a record held by anauxiliary organization, the organization shall assist the person to make a focused and effective request thatreasonably describes an identifiable record or records.1/25/17, 10:54 AMBill Text - SB-8 Public records: auxiliary organizations and UC campus foundations. (a) Upon a written request for a copy or inspection of records, an auxiliary organization shall determine,within 10 calendar days from the receipt of the request, whether the request, in whole or in part, seeks copiesof disclosable records maintained by the auxiliary organization and shall notify the requester in writing withoutundue delay of the determination and the reasons therefor.(b) (1) In unusual circumstances, the time limit prescribed in this section may be extended by a written noticeby the head of the auxiliary organization, or his or her designee, to the person making the request that setsforth the reasons for the extension and the date on which a determination is expected to be sent. That noticeshall not specify a date that would result in an extension of more than 14 days. When the auxiliaryorganization sends the determination, and if the auxiliary organization determines that the request seeksdisclosable public records, the auxiliary organization shall state the estimated date and time when the recordswill be made available.(2) As used in this section, "unusual circumstances" means the following, but only to the extent reasonablynecessary to the proper processing of the particular request:(A) The need to search for and collect the requested records from field facilities or other establishments thatare separate from the office processing the request.(B) The need to search for, collect, and appropriately examine a voluminous amount of separate and distinctrecords that are demanded in a single request.(C) The need for consultation, which shall be conducted with all practicable speed, with another agency havinga substantial interest in the determination of the request or among two or more components of the agencyhaving a substantial subject matter interest therein.(D) The need to compile data, to write programming language or a computer program, or to construct acomputer report to extract data.(c) An auxiliary organization shall justify withholding a record by demonstrating that the record is exemptfrom disclosure by law, or that, on the facts of the particular request, the public interest served by notdisclosing the record clearly outweighs the public interest served by disclosure of the record.(d) A response to a written request for inspection or copies of public records that includes a determination thatthe request is denied, in whole or in part, shall be in writing and shall set forth the names and titles orpositions of each person responsible for the denial.(e) This article shall not limit access to a public record on the basis of the purpose for which the record isbeing requested, if the record is otherwise subject to disclosure.72694. (a) Unless otherwise prohibited by law, an auxiliary organization that has information that constitutesan identifiable record not exempt from disclosure pursuant to this chapter that is in an electronic format shallmake that record available in an electronic format when requested by any person and, when applicable, shallcomply with both of the following:(1) An auxiliary organization shall make an electronic record available in the electronic format in which it holdsthe information.(2) An auxiliary organization shall provide a copy of an electronic record in the format requested if therequested format is one that has been used by the auxiliary organization to create copies for its own use or forprovision to other entities or persons. The cost of duplication shall be limited to the direct cost of producing acopy of a record in an electronic format.(b) Notwithstanding paragraph (2) of subdivision (a), the requester shall bear the cost of producing a copy ofthe record, including the cost to construct a record, and the cost of programming and computer servicesnecessary to produce a copy of the record if either of the following applies:(1) In order to comply with the provisions of subdivision (a), an auxiliary organization would be required to1/25/17, 10:54 AMBill Text - SB-8 Public records: auxiliary organizations and UC campus foundations. Page 4 of 15http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billNavClient.xhtml?bill_id=201120120SB8produce a copy of an electronic record and the record is one that is produced only at otherwise regularlyscheduled intervals.(2) The request would require data compilation, extraction, or programming to produce the record.(c) If a request is for a record in a nonelectronic format, and the record is also available in an electronicformat, an auxiliary organization may inform the requester that the record is available in an electronic format.(d) Nothing in this section shall be construed to do any of the following:(1) Require an auxiliary organization to reconstruct a record in an electronic format if the auxiliaryorganization no longer has the record available in an electronic format.(2) Permit an auxiliary organization to make a record available only in an electronic format.(3) Require an auxiliary organization to release an electronic record in the electronic form in which it is held bythe auxiliary organization if its release would jeopardize or compromise the security or integrity of the originalrecord, or of any proprietary software with which it is maintained.(4) Permit public access to records held by an auxiliary organization to which access is otherwise restricted bylaw.72695. Nothing in this article shall require an auxiliary organization to disclose information that is exempt fromdisclosure pursuant to the exemptions set forth under Sections 6254 to 6255, inclusive, of the GovernmentCode.72696. (a) Notwithstanding any other law, the following records maintained by an auxiliary organization shallnot be subject to disclosure:(1) Information that would disclose the identity of a donor, prospective donor, or volunteer.(2) Personal financial information, estate planning information, and gift planning information of a donor,prospective donor, or volunteer.(3) Personal information related to a donor's private trusts or a donor's private annuities administered by anauxiliary organization.(4) Information related to fundraising plans, fundraising research, and solicitation strategies to the extent thatthese activities are not already protected under Section 99040, Title 5 (commencing with Section 3426) ofPart 1 of Division 4 of the Civil Code, Section 1060 of the Evidence Code, or subdivision (k) of Section 6254 ofthe Government Code.(5) The identity of students and alumni to the extent that this information is already protected under state andfederal statutes applicable to the California Community Colleges. This paragraph shall not apply to a part-timeor full-time employee of the auxiliary organization, or to a student who participates in a legislative body of astudent body organization that operates on a campus of a California Community College.(b) Subdivision (a) shall not be construed to exempt from disclosure records that contain informationregarding any of the following:(1) The amount and date of a donation.(2) Any donor-designated use or purpose of a donation.(3) Any other donor-imposed restrictions on the use of a donation.(4) (A) The identity of a donor who, in any fiscal year, makes a gift or gifts, in a quid pro quo arrangement,where either the value of the benefit received is in excess of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500) orthe benefit would be impermissible under state or federal law. (a) Notwithstanding any provision of law, trade secrets, as defined in Section 3426.1 of the Civil Code,shall not be subject to disclosure. This information shall be redacted from auxiliary organization records beforedisclosure.(b) For purposes of this section, "trade secrets" means information, including a formula, pattern, compilation,program, device, method, technique, or process, that does both of the following:(1) Derives independent economic value, actual or potential, from not being generally known to the public orto other persons who can obtain economic value from its disclosure or use.(2) Is the subject of efforts that are reasonable under the circumstances to maintain its secrecy.72697. Any person may institute proceedings for injunctive or declarative relief or writ of mandate in any courtof competent jurisdiction to enforce his or her right to inspect or to receive a copy of any record or class ofrecords maintained by an auxiliary organization under this article. The times for responsive pleadings and forhearings in these proceedings shall be set by the judge of the court with the object of securing a decision as tothese matters at the earliest possible time.72698. (a) Whenever it is made to appear by verified petition to the superior court of the county where therecords or some part thereof are situated that certain records maintained by an auxiliary organization arebeing improperly withheld from a member of the public, the court shall order the officer or person chargedwith withholding the records to disclose the record or show cause why he or she should not do so. The courtshall decide the case after examining the record in camera, if permitted by subdivision (b) of Section 915 ofthe Evidence Code, papers filed by the parties, and any oral argument and additional evidence as the courtmay allow.(b) If the court finds that an auxiliary organization official's decision to refuse disclosure is not justified underthis article, he or she shall order the official to make the record public. If the judge determines that the officialwas justified in refusing to make the record public, he or she shall return the item to the official withoutdisclosing its content with an order supporting the decision refusing disclosure.(c) An order of the court, either directing disclosure by an auxiliary organization or supporting the decision ofthe auxiliary organization official refusing disclosure, is not a final judgment or order within the meaning ofSection 904.1 of the Code of Civil Procedure from which an appeal may be taken, but shall be immediatelyreviewable by petition to the appellate court for the issuance of an extraordinary writ. Upon entry of any orderpursuant to this section, a party shall, in order to obtain review of the order, file a petition within 20 days afterservice upon him or her of a written notice of entry of the order, or within such further time not exceeding anadditional 20 days as the trial court may for good cause allow. If the notice is served by mail, the period within1/25/17, 10:54 AMBill Text - SB-8 Public records: auxiliary organizations and UC campus foundations. Any person who fails to obey the order of the court shall be cited to show cause why he or she isnot in contempt of court.(d) The court shall award court costs and reasonable attorney's fees to the plaintiff should the plaintiff prevailin litigation filed pursuant to this section. EMAIL FROM ROBERT E. GRIFFIN (1/22/17) Re: California Public Records Act Clean-Up — CLRC Study G-400 Barbara & Steve: In 2011, the State Legislature enacted The Richard McKee Transparency Act of 2011 -- SB 8 (Stats, 2011, c. 247, Sec 2.), adding Education Code Sections 89913 to 89919. This law has represented an awkward and largely unnecessarily detailed overlay of the CPRA.
